entry.et: Middle English, from Old English, Anglo-French, & Latin; Old English lacu stream, pool, from Latin lacus lake, pool, pit & Anglo-French lac pit, from Latin lacus; akin to Old English lagu sea, Greek lakkos pond

def.dt: :a considerable inland body of standing water
:a pool of other liquid (as lava, oil, or pitch)

entry.et: French laque lac, from Old Occitan laca, from Arabic lakk lacquer

def.dt: :a purplish red pigment prepared from lac or cochineal
:any of numerous usually bright translucent organic pigments composed essentially of a soluble dye absorbed on or combined with an inorganic carrier
:to cause (blood) to undergo a physiological change in which the hemoglobin becomes dissolved in the plasma
:to undergo the process by which hemoglobin becomes dissolved in the plasma
:a dwelling built on piles in a lake

:a meteorological phenomenon in which warm moist air rising from a body of water mixes with cold dry air overhead resulting in precipitation especially downwind usually hyphenated when used attributively lake-effect snows
:a cisco (Coregonus artedii) found from the Mississippi River basin, Great Lakes, and St. Lawrence River northward and important as a commercial food fish
:any of various trout and salmon found in lakes
reservation S cen Alaska WSW of Anchorage containing scenic wilderness, abundant wildlife
area NW England in S Cumbria & NW Lancashire containing many lakes & peaks
